facts.text: Petitions filed under Article 32 of the Constitution by proprietors of lands in Rajasthan challenging vires of Ordinance No. IX of 1949, notifications dated June 14, 1951 and June 20, 1953, and Act No. X of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: These are petitions filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution by proprietors of lands in the State of Rajasthan, challenging the vires of The Rajasthan  Protection of Tenants  Ordinance, 1949, Ordinance No. IX of 1949, hereinafter referred to as the Ordinance, of numberifications dated June 14, 1951 and June 20, 1953, issued thereunder and of the Rajasthan  Protection of Tenants  Amendment Act No. X of 1954.

facts.text: Rajputana consisted of 18 principalities claiming sovereign status under British rule.

anchor.surface_text: When the British were the Rulers of this Country, Rajputana, as the State was then known, companysisted of 18 principalities claiming sovereign status.

facts.text: All principalities merged into United State of Rajasthan on May 5, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: After independence, a movement was set afoot for the integration of all the principalities into a single State, and the process was companypleted on May 5, 1949, when all of them became merged in a Union called the United State of Rajasthan.

facts.text: Constitution of the State settled in a Covenant agreed by all Rulers.

anchor.surface_text: The companystitution of the State was settled in a Covenant, to which all the Rulers agreed.

facts.text: Legislative Assembly of Rajasthan constituted on March 29, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned that the Legislative Assembly of Rajasthan was companystituted and came into being on March 29, 1952, and until then, it was the Rajpramukh in whom the Legislative authority of the State was vested.

facts.text: Rajpramukh promulgated Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Ordinance No. IX of 1949 on June 21, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: On June 21, 1949, the Rajpramukh promulgated the impugned legislation, the Rajasthan  Protection of Tenants  Ordinance No. IX of 1949.

facts.text: Preamble to Ordinance states view to check landholders ejecting tenants and increase foodgrains production.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble to the Ordinance runs as follows Whereas with a view to putting a check on the growing tendency of landholders to eject or dispossess tenants from their holdings, and in the wider national interest of increasing the production of foodgrains, it is expedient to make provisions for the protection of tenants in Rajasthan from ejectment or dispossession from their holdings.

facts.text: Section 4 of Ordinance: No tenant liable to ejectment while Ordinance in force.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 of the Ordinance provides So long as the Ordinance is in force in any area of Rajasthan, numbertenant shall be liable to ejectment or dispossession from the whole or a part of his holding in such area on any ground whatsoever.

facts.text: Section 7 provides reinstatement for tenants in occupation on first day of April 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 provides for reinstatement of tenants who had been in occupation on the first day of April, 1948, but had been subsequently dispossessed

facts.text: Section 3(1) of Ordinance: In force for two years unless extended by Rajpramukh by notification.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 1  of the Ordinance, which is very material for the present petitions, runs as follows It shall companye into force at once, and shall remain in force for a period of two years unless this period is further extended by the Rajpramukh by numberification in the Rajasthan Gazette.

facts.text: Rajpramukh issued notification on June 14, 1951 extending Ordinance for two years from June 21, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the power companyferred by this section, the Rajpramukh issued a numberification on June 14, 195 1, providing that Ordinance No. IX of 1949 shall remain in force for a further period of two years with effect from June 21, 1951.

facts.text: Rajpramukh issued notification on June 20, 1953 extending Ordinance for one year from June 21, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: On June 20, 1953, he issued a further numberification providing that the said Ordinance shall remain in force for a term of one year with effect from June 21, 1953.

facts.text: Rajpramukh issued Ordinance No. III of 1954 on February 15, 1954 substituting s.3 for five years operation.

anchor.surface_text: To resolve the doubt, the Rajpramukh issued on February 15, 1954, an Ordinance under Art. 238 of the Constitution,, No. III of 1954, substituting for s. 3 the following It shall companye into force at once and shall remain in force for a period of five years

facts.text: Rajasthan Protection of Tenants Amendment Act No. X of 1954 came into force on April 17, 1954 re-enacting s.3 for seven years.

anchor.surface_text: Then the Legislature of the State repealed Ordinance No. III of 1954, and enacted the Rajasthan  Protection of Tenants  Amendment Act No. X of 1954, and that came into force on April 17, 1954. Under this Act, a. 3 of Ordinance No. IX of 1949 was re-enacted as follows It shall companye into force at once and shall remain in force for a period of seven years.

facts.text: Rajasthan Tenancy Act No. III of 1955 came into force on October 15, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on October 15, 1955, a new enactment, the Rajasthan Tenancy Act No. III of 1955, came into force,

facts.text: Petitions by tenants under Ordinance No. IX of 1949 still undisposed due to stay orders by petitioners.

anchor.surface_text: But as a large number of petitions filed by the tenants under Ordinance No. IX of 1949 are still undisposed of by reason of stay orders obtained by the petitioners herein,

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 8, 1957 by Venkatarama Ayyar J.

anchor.surface_text: 1957. February 8. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by VENKATARAMA AYYAR J.-These are petitions filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution by proprietors of lands in the State of Rajasthan,

facts.text: Petitioners contend notifications dated June 14, 1951 and June 20, 1953 are bad as s.3 constitutes delegation of legislative power.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for petitioners urged the following companytentions in support of the petitions The numberifications dated June 14, 1951, and June 20, 1953, are bad, as s. 3 of the Ordinance under which they were issued is ultra vires, as companystituting delegation of legislative power.

facts.text: Petitioners contend notification June 20, 1953 bad because Legislature constituted on March 29, 1952 ending Rajpramukh's authority under Art. 385.

anchor.surface_text: The numberification dated June 20,1953, is further bad, because the Legislature of Rajasthan had been companystituted on March 29, 1952, and the authority of the Rajpramukh to legislate companyferred by Art. 385 of the Constitution had, on that date, companye to an end.

facts.text: Petitioners contend Act No. X of 1954 bad as it extends life of expired Ordinance No. IX of 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Act No. X of 1954 is bad, as it purports to extend the life of Ordinance No. IX of 1949 after the said Ordinance had already become dead.

facts.text: Court holds s.3 of Ordinance is conditional legislation, not delegated, and valid.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion,, s. 3 of the Ordinance in so far as it authorises the Rajpramukh to extend the life of the Act falls within the category of companyditional legislation, and is, in companysequence, intra vires.

facts.text: Court holds notification of June 20, 1953 valid as exercise of power under s.3, not independent legislation.

anchor.surface_text: The true position is that it is in his character as the authority on whom power was companyferred under s. 3 of the Ordinance that the Rajpramukh issued the impugned numberification, and number as the legislative authority of the State. This objection should accordingly be overruled.

facts.text: Court holds Ordinance not repugnant to Art. 14.

anchor.surface_text: We must accordingly hold that the impugned Ordinance cannot be held to be bad under Art. 14.

facts.text: Petitioners are landlords, respondents include State of Rajasthan and Board of Revenue.

anchor.surface_text: Porus A. Mehta and T. M. Sen, for the State of Rajasthan and Board of Revenue in all the Petitions.

arguments.claim: s. 3 ... authorises the Rajpramukh to extend the life of the Act falls within the category of conditional legislation, and is, in consequence, intra vires.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, s. 3 of the Ordinance in so far as it authorises the Rajpramukh to extend the life of the Act falls within the category of conditional legislation, and is, in consequence, intra vires.

arguments.claim: when an appropriate Legislature enacts a law and authorises an outside authority to bring it into force ... that is conditional and not delegated legislation, and that such legislation is valid.

anchor.surface_text: one such proposition is that when an appropriate Legislature enacts a law and authorises an outside authority to bring it into force in such area or at such time as it may decide, that is conditional and not delegated legislation, and that such legislation is valid.

arguments.claim: provision conferring a power on an outside authority to bring it into force at such time as it might ... is conditional and not delegated legislation ... as laid down in The Queen v. Burah.

anchor.surface_text: This is clear authority that a provision in a statute conferring a power on an outside authority to bring it into force at such time as it might, in its own discretion, determine, is conditional and not delegated legislation, and that it will be valid ...

arguments.claim: the notification dated June 20, 1953, is ... merely an exercise of a power conferred by a statute which had been previously enacted ... The true position is that it is in his character as the authority on whom power was conferred under s. 3 ... not as the legislative authority.

anchor.surface_text: The true position is that it is in his character as the authority on whom power was conferred under s. 3 of the Ordinance that the Rajpramukh issued the impugned notification, and not as the legislative authority of the State. This objection should accordingly be overruled.

arguments.claim: the preamble ... recites that there was a growing tendency ... to eject tenants ... the Legislature had necessarily to decide from what date the law should be given operation ... That is a matter exclusively for the Legislature to determine.

anchor.surface_text: The preamble to the Ordinance recites that there was a growing tendency on the part of the landholders to eject tenants, and that it was therefore expedient to enact a law for giving them protection ... That is a matter exclusively for the Legislature to determine, and the propriety of that determination is not open to question in Courts.

arguments.claim: the preamble to the Ordinance sets out with sufficient clearness the policy of the Legislature and as that governs s. 15 of the Ordinance, the decision of the Government thereunder cannot be said to be unguided.

anchor.surface_text: It is true that that section does not itself indicate the grounds on which exemption could be granted, but the preamble to the Ordinance sets out with sufficient clearness the policy of the Legislature and as that governs s. 15 of the Ordinance, the decision of the Government thereunder cannot be said to be unguided. Vide Harishankar Bagla v. The State of Madhya Pradesh.

arguments.claim: even if s. 15 were to be held to be bad, that does not affect the rest of the legislation, as the matter dealt with in that section is clearly severable.

anchor.surface_text: But even if s. 15 were to be held to be bad, that does not affect the rest of the legislation, as the matter dealt with in that section is clearly severable.

arguments.claim: the object of the Ordinance ... is clearly not to put a restriction on the right of an owner to himself cultivate the lands, but to prevent him ... from getting rid of him without sufficient cause. A law which requires ... fixity of tenure, cannot ... be said to be unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: It is finally contended that the provisions of the Act are repugnant to Art. 19(1)(f) in that they oblige the land-owners to keep tenants on their lands ... The object of the Ordinance, as set out in the preamble, is clearly not to put a restriction on the right of an owner to himself cultivate the lands, but to prevent him when he had inducted a tenant on the land from getting rid of him without sufficient cause.

arguments.claim: the decision in Jatindra Nath Gupta ... cannot ... be regarded as a clear ... pronouncement that a statutory provision authorising an outside authority to extend the life of a statute is per se bad.

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Jatindra Nath Gupta v. The Province of Bihar cannot therefore be regarded as a clear and direct pronouncement that a statutory provision authorising an outside authority to extend the life of a statute is per se bad.

arguments.claim: the petitioners sought to dispute the correctness of the recitals in the preamble. This they clearly cannot do.

holdings.text: A law which requires that an owner who is not himself a tiller of the soil should assure to the actual tiller some fixity of tenure, cannot on that ground alone be said to be unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: The object of the Ordinance, as set out in the preamble, is clearly not to put a restriction on the right of an owner to himself cultivate the lands, but to prevent him when he had inducted a tenant on the land from getting rid of him without sufficient cause. A law which requires that an owner who is not himself a tiller of the soil should assure to the actual tiller some fixity of tenure, cannot on that ground alone be said to be unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Ordinance protects tenant tenure consistent with ownership rights; upheld as reasonable regulation; cites US precedents like Block v. Hirsh.

holdings.text: we are unable to agree with the statement of the law in Jatindra Nath Gupta v. The Province of Bihar that a power to extend the life of an enactment cannot validly be conferred on an outside authority.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that we are unable to agree with the statement of the law in Jatindra Nath Gupta v. The Province of Bihar that a power to extend the life of an enactment cannot validly be conferred on an outside authority.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clarifies that pure extension power (without modification) is valid conditional legislation, distinguishing Jatindra which involved inseparably linked modification.
